items.title: [Kottke.org] Water bankruptcy is a “chronic condition that develops when a place uses...
items.content_html: Water bankruptcy is a “chronic condition that develops when a place uses more water than nature can reliably replace, and when the damage to the natural assets that store and filter that water, such as aquifers and wetlands, becomes hard to reverse”.
items.summary: Water bankruptcy is a “chronic condition that develops when a place uses more water than nature can reliably replace, and when the damage to the natural assets that store and filter that water, such as aquifers and wetlands, becomes hard to reverse”.

items.title: [Boing Boing] California is completely drought-free for the first time in 25 years
items.content_html:
For the first time since December 2000, not a single square mile of California is classified as dry on the U.S. Drought Monitor. The last time the state reached this threshold was 25 years ago, the LA Times reports.

A series of powerful winter storms and atmospheric rivers swept across the state starting in October, right on schedule ‚Äî unlike last year. — Read the rest

The post California is completely drought-free for the first time in 25 years appeared first on Boing Boing.

items.content_html: The setback occurred hours after one of the world‚Äôs largest nuclear complexes restarted, ending more than a decade of dormancy following the 2011 Fukushima Daiichi meltdown.

items.title: [NYT > Business] Storm Poses Big Threats to Power Grids Across U.S.
items.content_html: Managers of electric grids say freezing temperatures and ice and snow could lead to power outages in many places, potentially leaving millions in the dark.

items.title: [BBC World News] Record snowfall leaves cars stuck and people stranded in Russia's Far East
items.content_html: Parts of Kamchatka Peninsula have been buried under its heaviest snowfall in 60 years, as scientists say the winter blast could be due to climate change.
items.summary: Parts of Kamchatka Peninsula have been buried under its heaviest snowfall in 60 years, as scientists say the winter blast could be due to climate change.

items.title: [Longreads] How to Become a Tree
items.content_html: "Many people today want to commit their remains to rejuvenating the planet. But are these green deaths just greenwashing?"
